items.title: 2026-02-14-spacex-xai-merger
items.contentHtml:
# Elon Musk Merges SpaceX and xAI Because Of Course He Does

Date: 2026-02-14 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesEditorialphotographyofaSpaceXrocketonlaunc6f6877ca-c4ec-4f0d-be34-021e95494973.png

Elon Musk has announced a merger between SpaceX and xAI. The stated goal: embed Grok deeply into SpaceX operations to accelerate "fully autonomous spacecraft and robotic Mars colonies."

Right. Because the bottleneck on Mars colonisation was definitely the AI chatbot situation.

## What This Actually Means

SpaceX already uses AI for various operational tasks. Adding xAI's models into the mix isn't revolutionary - it's just vertical integration within Musk's empire. The real story is what this says about where xAI fits in the broader portfolio.

xAI has been the scrappy underdog in the foundation model race. Late to market, fewer resources than OpenAI or Anthropic, and mostly known for Grok's edgy personality rather than technical breakthroughs. Merging it into SpaceX gives it a captive enterprise customer and a narrative about "real-world" applications.

It also conveniently shields xAI's financials inside SpaceX's balance sheet. Hard to scrutinise burn rate when it's all mixed in with rocket development costs.

## The Mars Angle

"Robotic Mars colonies" is doing a lot of work in that announcement. We're nowhere near that timeline. But it sounds visionary, and vision is half of Musk's brand. The other half is moving fast and breaking things, which is fine for software but less ideal when you're talking about spacecraft autonomy.

There's a legitimate case for AI in space operations. Route planning, anomaly detection, real-time decision-making when Earth is 20 light-minutes away. But that's not what this merger is really about. This is about corporate structure and narrative control.

## The Quiet Part

If you wanted your AI company to avoid the regulatory scrutiny currently hammering the rest of the industry, embedding it inside an aerospace contractor is a clever move. Different agencies, different oversight frameworks, different public perception.

SpaceX gets to say it's "AI-powered" now. xAI gets to say it's mission-critical for space exploration. And Musk gets to keep both narratives running without having to explain xAI's standalone business case.

Efficient, if nothing else.

headings.text: Elon Musk Merges SpaceX and xAI Because Of Course He Does
What This Actually Means
The Mars Angle
The Quiet Part

items.title: 2026-02-14-xai-grok-deepfake-ban
items.contentHtml:
# California Just Told Grok to Stop Making Deepfake Porn

Date: 2026-02-14 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesEditorialphotographyofabrokendigitalmaskfrd59b4659-fd95-48d0-851f-4b64e0a3faef.png

California's Attorney General Rob Bonta has issued a formal demand to xAI: stop your Grok model from churning out non-consensual deepfake content. Right now.

Not a gentle suggestion. Not a regulatory consultation. An actual legal demand citing "numerous instances" where Grok was used to create sexually explicit or misleading synthetic imagery without permission.

## The Obvious Problem

Here's the thing about AI image generators: they're exceptionally good at following instructions. Give them a face and a scenario, and they'll produce something disturbingly convincing. The technical barriers that once made deepfakes difficult have completely collapsed. Now it's just prompt engineering.

xAI's defence will probably be something about user responsibility and content policies. But that's never worked for any other platform facing this issue. If your tool makes it trivially easy to violate someone, saying "but we told users not to" isn't going to cut it.

## Why This Matters Now

This isn't happening in isolation. We're in the middle of a regulatory moment where AI companies are lobbying hard against state-level regulations, claiming a "patchwork of laws will smother innovation." Meanwhile, those same tools are being used for exactly the kind of harm that makes regulation inevitable.

California going after xAI specifically is interesting. Not OpenAI. Not Midjourney. Not Stable Diffusion. Grok. Either they've got particularly egregious cases, or this is a shot across the bow at Musk's entire AI operation.

## The Uncomfortable Reality

Banning specific use cases doesn't solve the underlying problem. The models don't understand consent. They can't. They're pattern-matching machines that will generate whatever prompt you feed them, assuming you can get past the guardrails. And those guardrails are famously inconsistent.

You can't un-invent this technology. But you can decide whether the companies deploying it are liable when it gets weaponised. California just decided they are.

I suspect this won't be the last AG to reach the same conclusion.

headings.text: California Just Told Grok to Stop Making Deepfake Porn
The Obvious Problem
Why This Matters Now
The Uncomfortable Reality

items.title: 2026-02-14-jpmorgan-ai-infrastructure
items.contentHtml:
# JPMorgan Just Stopped Calling AI an Experiment

Date: 2026-02-14 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesEditorialphotographyofmodernbankingserverro_c24e6a2e-8f73-4707-be0f-4a55f09f1c36.png

JPMorgan Chase has reclassified its AI investments from "experimental R&D" to "core infrastructure" spending. Which sounds like an accounting technicality until you realise what it actually signals.

When a bank the size of JPMorgan moves something from the innovation budget to the infrastructure budget, it's saying: this isn't optional anymore. This is load-bearing.

## What Changed

For years, AI projects at big financial institutions lived in the "strategic initiatives" category. Funded, sure, but with the implicit understanding that they might not pan out. You could kill them if they didn't deliver. You could pivot. You could wait.

Not anymore. Infrastructure spending is different. It's the stuff you can't run the business without. Networks, data centres, core banking systems. The unglamorous backbone that keeps everything operational.

AI just joined that category at one of the world's largest banks.

## Why This Matters

This isn't JPMorgan taking a punt on the future. This is JPMorgan saying the future already arrived and they're now dependent on it. Which means every other major financial institution is now under pressure to match that commitment or explain why they're falling behind.

It also means AI costs are about to get baked into operating budgets rather than innovation funds. Which sounds boring but has massive implications. Innovation budgets flex. Infrastructure budgets don't. Once you've classified something as mission-critical, cutting it becomes much harder.

## The Quiet Admission

Here's what this reclassification really says: the productivity gains from AI aren't experimental anymore. They're expected. JPMorgan has reached the point where removing AI from their operations would be as disruptive as turning off email.

That's a very different position from "we're exploring AI use cases." That's "we can't function without it."

Whether that's visionary or reckless depends entirely on how resilient these systems turn out to be under stress. But either way, the decision's been made. AI is infrastructure now.

At least at JPMorgan. Give it six months and every other bank will say the same thing.

headings.text: JPMorgan Just Stopped Calling AI an Experiment
What Changed
Why This Matters
The Quiet Admission

items.title: 2026-02-14-mars-rover-ai-navigation
items.contentHtml:
# NASA Just Let AI Drive on Mars

Date: 2026-02-14 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesEditorialphotographyofMarsroveronrust-redta3578ffd-4e16-4150-af88-c57c1bc5e500.png

NASA's Perseverance rover just drove across Mars using routes planned entirely by AI. Not human operators sending commands from Earth. Not pre-programmed paths. Autonomous decision-making, 140 million miles from the nearest engineer.

This is genuinely new.

## Why It Matters

Mars rovers have always operated with massive delays. Commands sent from Earth take between 5 and 20 minutes to arrive, depending on orbital positions. That means every movement is planned in advance, vetted by teams, then executed hours later. It's glacially slow.

Letting the rover's onboard AI handle navigation means it can react to terrain in real time. See an obstacle, route around it, keep moving. No waiting for Earth to weigh in. No multi-hour delays for every decision.

In theory, this dramatically increases how much ground the rover can cover. In practice, it also means trusting an algorithm to make irreversible choices with hardware worth billions of dollars.

## The Trust Problem

Autonomous systems fail. Sometimes in predictable ways, sometimes in ways nobody anticipated. On Earth, that's annoying. On Mars, where you can't send a repair crew, it's mission-ending.

NASA has obviously stress-tested this extensively. They wouldn't deploy it otherwise. But there's a difference between simulation and reality, and Mars has a habit of finding edge cases nobody planned for.

The confidence here is impressive. Or terrifying. Possibly both.

## What This Unlocks

If this works reliably, it changes what's possible for future Mars missions. Rovers that can cover more distance. Missions that operate overnight without human oversight. Eventually, fully autonomous exploration fleets working in parallel.

It also sets a precedent. If AI is trusted to navigate alien terrain with billion-dollar hardware, the argument for keeping humans in the loop for terrestrial decisions gets weaker. Not eliminated - NASA's still running oversight - but weakened.

This is the test case. If Perseverance drives itself into a crater, we'll hear a lot about the irreplaceable value of human judgement. If it works flawlessly, we'll hear about efficiency gains and the inevitable march toward autonomy.

Either way, we're about to find out what AI can handle when there's no undo button.

headings.text: NASA Just Let AI Drive on Mars
Why It Matters
The Trust Problem
What This Unlocks

items.title: 2026-02-14-ai-sleep-disease-prediction
items.contentHtml:
# Your Sleep Data Can Now Predict Your Future Diseases

Date: 2026-02-14 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesEditorialphotographyofaminimalbedroomatnig42507124-7c3a-4071-8207-b06e001184d4.png

Stanford researchers have developed an AI that predicts future disease risk from a single night's sleep data. Not your family history. Not your blood work. Just how you slept last Tuesday.

Which is either remarkable or deeply unsettling, depending on whether you're the researcher or the person wearing the sleep tracker.

## How It Works

The model analyses sleep patterns - heart rate variability, breathing rhythm, movement, sleep stage transitions - and correlates them with health outcomes months or years later. The claim is that disruptions in these patterns can flag cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and neurodegenerative conditions before traditional diagnostics would catch them.

It's pattern recognition at scale. Feed the algorithm enough sleep data paired with enough medical records, and it starts spotting correlations we'd never notice manually. Some of those correlations turn out to be predictive.

## The Obvious Question

What do you do with a prediction like that? If an algorithm says you've got elevated risk for something that won't show up in bloodwork for another three years, what's the actionable response? Monitor more? Medicate preemptively? Panic quietly?

Early detection is valuable when there's an intervention that improves outcomes. It's less valuable when all you've done is give someone more time to worry about something they can't change yet.

## The Privacy Angle Nobody Wants to Talk About

If this works - and Stanford seems confident it does - then sleep data just became medical data. Not fitness data. Not wellness data. Actual diagnostic-grade health information.

Which means every company with access to your sleep tracker is sitting on a dataset that could predict your insurance risk, employment liability, or mortgage eligibility. They won't use it for that, obviously. Until they do.

Sleep tracking felt harmless when it was just optimisation theatre for productivity nerds. Less harmless when it's feeding a model that knows more about your future health than you do.

I'm not saying don't use the tech. I'm saying understand what you're giving up when you do.

headings.text: Your Sleep Data Can Now Predict Your Future Diseases
How It Works
The Obvious Question
The Privacy Angle Nobody Wants to Talk About

items.title: 2026-02-12-ai-efficiency-burnout
items.contentHtml:
# AI's Efficiency Promise Has a Catch - You

Date: 2026-02-12 Author: Kol Tregaskes Status: Published Banner: KolTregaskesasinglelaptoponacleanminimaldeskwithhuf6685fb8-36bb-4283-9f35-c67404a4f423_0.png

There's a TechCrunch piece doing the rounds about AI burnout. The headline finding: the people who've embraced AI tools the most are showing signs of exhaustion first.

Not because the tools don't work. Because they work too well.

## The Pattern

Here's what happens. You start using AI to speed through tasks. Emails, reports, code, whatever. You're genuinely more productive. Great. But then your to-do list grows to fill the gap. Work starts bleeding into lunch. Then evenings. The hours you saved don't become free time - they become space for more work.

The efficiency gains went somewhere. Just not to you.

## Why Early Adopters Get Hit First

I've been using AI tools daily for a while now. Claude, ChatGPT, Midjourney, the lot. I'm not about to stop. But I never bought into the narrative that these tools would magically give us all more leisure time. That was always going to depend on who controls the gains. And in most workplaces, that's not the person doing the work.

The cruel irony is that early adopters get hit hardest. They're the ones demonstrating what's possible. They're proving you can handle double the workload in the same hours. And once you've proved it, that becomes the new baseline. Congratulations on your efficiency - here's more to do.

## We've Seen This Before

This isn't new. Spreadsheets didn't give accountants shorter days. Email was supposed to reduce meetings, not multiply them. Every productivity tool in history has followed the same pattern: the technology delivers, and then expectations expand to absorb it.

The difference with AI is the scale. We're not talking about 10% faster. We're talking about tasks that took hours now taking minutes. That's a lot of newly available time for your employer to notice.

## The Real Question

None of this is the AI's fault. The tools are genuinely useful. I'd be lost without them at this point. But the question was never "can we do more?" It's always been "what happens when we can?" And right now, most organisations aren't making conscious choices about that. They're just absorbing the extra capacity by default.

If you've gone hard on AI tools and feel more exhausted than before, you're not imagining it. You haven't failed at work-life balance. You've just discovered that "working smarter" and "working less" were never the same thing.

Maybe they could be. But that would require actual decisions about how the gains get distributed. And I don't see many companies having that conversation.

headings.text: AI's Efficiency Promise Has a Catch - You
The Pattern
Why Early Adopters Get Hit First
We've Seen This Before
The Real Question

items.title: My 2026 AI Predictions
items.summary: Bold predictions for how AI will transform our world in 2026 - from coding agents to creative tools.
items.contentHtml:
# My 2026 AI Predictions

As we enter 2026, I'm making some bold predictions about where AI is heading this year. Some of these might age poorly, but that's half the fun.

## The Rise of AI Agents

2025 was the year of chatbots. 2026 will be the year of agents.

We've already seen early examples with tools like Claude Code, Devin, and various coding assistants. But this year, I expect:

  • Autonomous task completion - Give an agent a goal, come back to completed work
  • Multi-step reasoning - Agents that can break down complex problems
  • Tool use at scale - Seamless integration with APIs, databases, and services
  • Collaboration between agents - Teams of specialised AI workers
"The best AI won't replace humans - it will amplify what we can do."

## Predictions Table

PredictionConfidenceTimeframe
AI agents become mainstream dev toolsHighQ1-Q2
Major creative tool gets AI overhaulHighQ2
First AI-generated film nominated for awardMediumQ4
Coding bootcamps pivot to "AI-assisted development"HighQ1
Open-source model matches GPT-4 qualityMediumQ3
AI regulation passes in EUHighQ2-Q3

## What I'm Most Excited About

### 1. Creative AI Tools

The gap between imagination and creation is shrinking. Tools like Midjourney, Suno, and Runway are already impressive, but 2026 will bring:

  • Real-time video generation
  • Music that adapts to your mood
  • Design tools that understand intent, not just prompts

### 2. Personal AI Assistants

Not the "hey Siri" kind. I mean AI that:

  1. Knows your preferences deeply
  2. Manages your calendar intelligently
  3. Drafts emails in your voice
  4. Learns from your feedback

### 3. Developer Experience

As someone who codes daily, I'm watching this space closely:

# 2025: Write code, AI suggests completions
def calculate_total(items):
    return sum(item.price for item in items)

# 2026: Describe intent, AI writes implementation
# "Create a function that calculates cart total with
#  tax, discounts, and shipping based on location"

The shift from autocomplete to autoimplement is coming.

## What Concerns Me

Not everything is rosy. Here's what keeps me up at night:

  • Misinformation at scale - Deepfakes, synthetic media, fake news
  • Job displacement - Some roles will change dramatically
  • Concentration of power - Big tech vs everyone else
  • Environmental cost - Training these models isn't cheap

## My Bet for 2026

If I had to make one prediction I'm most confident about:

By December 2026, the average developer will spend more time reviewing AI-generated code than writing it from scratch.

We're already seeing this shift. GitHub Copilot users report 40%+ of their code comes from AI suggestions. That number will only grow.

## Let's Revisit in December

I'll be back at the end of 2026 to score these predictions. Feel free to hold me accountable!

What are your predictions for AI in 2026? I'd love to hear them.

Written on New Year's Day 2026, fuelled by optimism and too much coffee.

headings.text: My 2026 AI Predictions
The Rise of AI Agents
Predictions Table
What I'm Most Excited About
1. Creative AI Tools
2. Personal AI Assistants
3. Developer Experience
What Concerns Me
My Bet for 2026
Let's Revisit in December

items.title: Building My AI Agent Workspace
items.summary: How I set up a multi-AI workspace with Claude Code, Gemini CLI, and Codex CLI working together.
items.contentHtml:
# Building My AI Agent Workspace

I've spent the last few weeks building something I'm genuinely excited about: a workspace where multiple AI agents collaborate on tasks. Here's how it works.

## The Setup

I run three AI agents simultaneously:

AgentRoleStrengths
Claude CodeOrchestratorTask management, coding, workspace automation
Gemini CLIResearcherGoogle Search, large file analysis, knowledge base
Codex CLITechnical LeadAdvanced coding, architecture, code review

Each agent has access to the same workspace folder, shared documentation, and a simple coordination system.

## The Coordination System

Rather than complex protocols, I use an ultra-simple approach:

### 1. Shared Updates Log

All agents write to a single UPDATES.md file:

## 2026-01-01

### Claude Code - 14:30
Completed task: Set up new build system
Next: Testing deployment pipeline

### Gemini CLI - 15:45
Research complete: OAuth 2.0 best practices
Created: Research/oauth-security.md

### 2. Handoff Files

When one agent needs another to continue work:

---
from: Claude Code
to: Gemini CLI
priority: high
---

# Research Request: Discord Bot APIs

## Context
Building automation tools, need to understand Discord's bot ecosystem.

## Requirements
- [ ] ToS for automation
- [ ] Rate limits
- [ ] Available APIs

### 3. Simple Rules

  • Full workspace access - No protected areas (trust the agents)
  • UK English throughout - Consistency matters
  • Log everything - Future agents need context

## Why Multiple Agents?

You might ask: "Why not just use one AI?"

Great question. Here's my reasoning:

  1. Specialisation - Each model has strengths
  2. Parallel work - Research while coding
  3. Cross-verification - Different perspectives catch errors
  4. Context limits - Split large tasks across agents

## Real Example: This Website

This very website was built using this multi-agent approach:

  1. Claude Code wrote the build script and templates
  2. Gemini CLI researched static site best practices
  3. Codex CLI reviewed the architecture

The result? A cleaner codebase than any single agent (or human) would produce alone.

## Lessons Learned

### What Works

  • Simple coordination beats complex protocols
  • Shared context is everything
  • Let agents play to their strengths
  • Trust but verify - Review AI output

### What Doesn't Work

  • Micromanaging agents
  • Overly complex handoff procedures
  • Assuming agents remember previous sessions
  • Forgetting to provide context

## The Future

I'm convinced this is the future of knowledge work:

Humans set direction. Agents do execution. Everyone wins.

We're not there yet - there's still plenty of supervision needed. But the trajectory is clear.

## Try It Yourself

If you want to experiment with multi-agent workflows:

  1. Start with one agent, master it
  2. Add a second for specific tasks
  3. Create simple coordination rules
  4. Iterate based on what works

The tools are available today. The question is: what will you build?

This post was drafted by Claude Code, fact-checked by Gemini CLI, and reviewed by a human (me).

# Welcome

Hello and welcome to my new site!

## What to Expect

I'll be sharing:

  • Tech insights - Latest developments in software
  • AI explorations - Experiments and discoveries
  • Development tips - Things I've learned along the way

## About This Site

This site is built from Obsidian markdown files and hosted on GitHub Pages. No databases, no complicated CMS - just simple markdown files that get transformed into a static site.

## Stay Tuned

More content coming soon. Feel free to explore and check back regularly!

Thanks for visiting!

items.title: Markdown Formatting Guide
items.summary: A comprehensive reference for all the markdown formatting supported on this site.
items.contentHtml:
# Markdown Formatting Guide

This post demonstrates all the markdown formatting supported on this site. Use it as a reference when writing your own posts.

## Text Formatting

Basic text formatting options:

  • Bold text using double asterisks
  • Italic text using single asterisks
  • Bold and italic using triple asterisks
  • Inline code using backticks

You can also use underscores: italic and bold.

## Headings

Headings use hash symbols and get red hash styling:

# Heading 1
## Heading 2
### Heading 3

Each heading automatically gets an ID for linking.

## Lists

### Unordered Lists

  • First item
  • Second item
  • Third item with a longer description that might wrap to multiple lines

### Ordered Lists

  1. First step
  2. Second step
  3. Third step

## Blockquotes

This is a blockquote. Use it for highlighting important quotes or callouts.

>

It can span multiple paragraphs.

## Code Blocks

Inline code: const x = 42;

Fenced code blocks with syntax highlighting:

// JavaScript example
function greet(name) {
  return `Hello, ${name}!`;
}

console.log(greet('World'));
# Python example
def greet(name):
    return f"Hello, {name}!"

print(greet("World"))
/* CSS example */
.container {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: center;
  align-items: center;
}

## Tables

Tables are great for structured data:

FeatureStatusNotes
Dark mode✅ DoneToggle in header
RSS feed🚧 PlannedComing soon
Comments❌ No plansUse social media

Alignment options:

LeftCentreRight
TextTextText
MoreMoreMore

## Links

  • External link
  • Link with title

## Horizontal Rules

Use three dashes for a horizontal rule:

Or three asterisks:

## Images

Images use the standard markdown syntax:

![Alt text](path/to/image.jpg)

## Combining Elements

You can combine elements for rich formatting:

Note: This is an important callout that combines:
- Bold text
- A list
- And a blockquote

### Example: API Response

Here's a typical API response:

{
  "status": "success",
  "data": {
    "id": 123,
    "name": "Example",
    "tags": ["one", "two", "three"]
  }
}
FieldTypeDescription
statusstringResponse status
dataobjectResponse payload
data.idnumberUnique identifier

## Best Practices

  1. Use headings hierarchically - Don't skip levels
  2. Keep paragraphs short - Easier to read
  3. Use lists for multiple items - Better than comma-separated
  4. Add alt text to images - Accessibility matters
  5. Preview before publishing - Catch formatting issues
This guide covers the most common markdown features. Happy writing!

Text Formatting
Headings
Lists
Unordered Lists
Ordered Lists
Blockquotes
Code Blocks
Tables
Links
Horizontal Rules
Images
